profile_data.summary:
I am a passionate Machine Learning and AI Engineer with a Master's in Computer Science from NYU, specializing in developing innovative AI-driven solutions for healthcare, natural language processing, and computer vision. Currently, I am a Researcher at NYU Courant, where I focus on pathology extraction from MRI reports using open-source Large Language Models (LLMs) and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), achieving a retrieval recall of 98%.

During my academic and professional experiences, I have successfully led various projects, such as building a web application to manage over 890,000 digital items for the New York Public Library. By integrating a custom Vision Transformer and Flan-T5 LLM, I enhanced the accessibility and organization of digital assets and reduced processing time by 45% through high-performance computing. My work on Hate-LLAMA, a multimodal audio-visual language model fine-tuned for hate speech detection, showcases my ability to address real-world challenges with cutting-edge AI technologies.

With a solid foundation in Python, PyTorch, NLP, and deep learning, I am eager to leverage my skills to develop AI applications that drive impact and innovation. I am particularly interested in opportunities within dynamic teams at startups or tech-driven organizations where I can contribute to AI/ML model development and application.

Let's connect to explore how we can work together to shape the future of AI! Feel free to connect via LinkedIn or contact me at ab10945@nyu.edu.


Skills: Python, PyTorch, NLP, Deep Learning, Computer Vision, Artificial Intelligence, Hugging Face, Scikit-Learn, Large Language Models (LLMs), Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), High-Performance Computing, DevOps (Kubernetes, Docker), Cloud Platforms (AWS, GCP).

education.description: MS in CS from Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences (New York University)

publications.name: A Sentiment Analysis Based Approach for Customer Segmentation
publications.publisher: Recent Patents on Engineering, Bentham Science Publisher
publications.description:
Background: Customer Segmentation is the process of dividing customers into groups based on some demographic factors to get an idea of the targeted audience for a product and to best market said product.

Objective: Sentiment Analysis of customer reviews is one way that this process can be enhanced to get not just demographic information but subjective information and preferences as well.

Methods: In this study, Long Short-Term Memory model, a deep learning technique has been applied for Sentiment Analysis and its results have been used to perform Customer Segmentation on demographic data containing information such as age and gender. Segmentation was performed using Spectral Clustering. Cluster Labels were extracted to perform supervised classification using different supervised algorithms, such as Support Vector Machines, Random Forests, Decision Trees and Logistic Regression.

Results: An accuracy of 90.9% was achieved by the LSTM model. An accuracy of 100% was achieved by the Random Forest and Decision Tree Classifiers.

Keywords: Customer Segmentation, Sentiment Analysis, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Spectral Clustering, Random Forests, Decision Trees

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

publications.name: BGP Anomaly Detection using Decision Tree Based Machine Learning Classifiers
publications.publisher: International Journal of Innovative Technology and Exploring Engineering (IJITEE)
publications.description: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is utilized to send and receive data packets over the internet. Over the years, this protocol has suffered from some massive hits, caused by worms, such as Nimda, Slammer, Code Red etc., hardware failures,and/or prefix hijacking. This caused obstruction of services to many. However, Identification of anomalous messages traversing over BGP allows discovering of such attacks in time. In this paper, a Machine Learning approach has been applied to identify such BGP messages. Principal Component Analysis technique was applied for reducing dimensionality up to 2 components, followed by generation of Decision Tree, Random Forest, AdaBoost and GradientBoosting classifiers. On fine tuning the parameters, the random forest classifier generated an accuracy of 97.84%, the decision tree classifier followed closely with an accuracy of 97.38%. The GradientBoosting Classifier gave an accuracy of 95.41% and the AdaBoost Classifier gave an accuracy of 94.43%.

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning
Technical Consulting Engineer at Cisco

publications.name: Using Linear Discriminant Analysis for Dimensionality Reduction for Predicting Anomalies of BGP data
publications.publisher: International Journal of Innovative Technology and Exploring Engineering (IJITEE)
publications.description: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is a vital protocol onthe internet for transfer of data packets among autonomous System (AS). Security is a major concern for the transmission of BGP packets which are often attacked by worms or are hijacked by an attacker which results in requests entering black holes or loss of connection to the particular sites. The BGP anomalies can be reduced by analyzing the BGP datasets. Since, ASes communicate through messages, therefore, the anomalies can be reduced by identifying the corrupted BGP message in the dataset. In this paper, BGP anomalies have been classified by applying Machine learning (ML) algorithms. The dataset contains information about the sending and receiving time between ASes. The classifiers were used to predict the anomalies. Since the dataset had high dimensions, the dimensions were reduced using Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) and then Support Vector Machines (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Linear Regression, Logistic Regression and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) have been used to classify the anomalies.

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning
Technical Consulting Engineer at Cisco

publications.name: Machine Learning Techniques to Reduce Error in the Internet of Things
publications.description: Over the years, Machine Learning (ML) techniques have been implemented to improve data processing speed and result in Internet of Things (IoT) devices. Some of the most common ML algorithms include Bayesian Statistics, Neural Networks, K Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machines (SVM), K means Clustering, Genetic Algorithms, decision trees, Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Random Forest, Regression Analysis. The aforementioned algorithms have been used for classification for various uses such as finding faults in the data, improve speeds by forming clusters of similar data points. ML can be used in varied fields such as to predict heart diseases, energy consumption, the state and location of IoT devices etc. This paper details the techniques and their usage in IoT.

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning
Technical Consulting Engineer at Cisco

publications.name: Survey On Applications Of Internet Of Things Using Machine Learning
publications.description: Over the past few years, the use of computer has spread through a lot of fields. By the connection of devices over the internet tasks can be carried out with much ease. The advancement of Machine Learning (ML) on the Internet of Things (IoT) has allowed researchers to find easier solutions to complicated day to day problems. ML techniques and algorithms such as Support Vector Machine (SVM), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), K means Clustering, Logistic regression can be used to generate devices such as smart surveillance systems, Smart Training Equipment (STE) and Smart Wearable Armband (SWA) for the improvement of conventional therapy or the detection of stress, heart rate, age related macular degeneration, process retinal images etc. IoT is also used in smart parking techniques by associating with the cloud and Big Data. This paper aims to study the different ML techniques used in the study of applications of IoT.

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description:
Devised AI agents to play the Trackmania F-1 racing game using the Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm, LIDAR inputs, and RNNs.
Experimented with pure LIDAR, LIDAR with track progress, and hybrid environments to optimize configurations.
Increased training efficiency by experimenting with sensory data integration and scored the best lap time of 35 second, approaching the 30-second human best.
Github Link: https://github.com/anishabhatnagar/RL-Racing
projects.title: Autonomous Racing with Reinforcement Learning

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description: Developed Hate-LLaMA, a multimodal audio-visual language model, with LLaMA-2-chat as the backbone, fine-tuned on the HateMM dataset for hate speech detection in online videos. Hate-LLaMA analyzes both visual frames and audio to classify hate speech, achieving an accuracy of 71%. Contributed to addressing the scarcity of labeled video datasets by proposing a benchmark dataset of 300 videos with 33% hate and 67% non-hate content for hate speech detection. Github Link: https://github.com/anishabhatnagar/Hate-LLaMA
projects.title: Hate-LLaMA: Hate Content Detection in Videos

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description: Developed an automated Video Summarization and Captioning framework. Utilized DSNet and Timesformer GPT-2 models to create concise video summaries and descriptive captions. Successfully processed diverse video datasets (TVSum and SumMe) and localized key content using anchor-based methods while maintaining temporal consistency. Github link: https://github.com/anishabhatnagar/Video-Summarization-and-Captioning.
projects.title: Video Summarisation and Captioning

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description:
The changes in the performance of Bert-style models, in Sentiment Analysis for Romanized Code-Switched inputs, were analyzed.
Pure Hindi (Devanagari), English translations, and Hindi transliterations were generated using GPT-3.5 and IndicXLIT models. 
TwHIN-Bert, mBERT, and XLM-T were evaluated in a zero-shot setting.
Consistent performance degradation of 4-9% was noted over all the experiments.
Github link: https://github.com/anishabhatnagar/hi-en-senti
projects.title: Bi-Lingual or Bye-Lingual? Code Switching in Hindi English Sentiment Analysis

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description:
Segmentation Masks were predicted for the 22nd future frame using only the first 11 frames of a sequence. An ensemble method, combining GANs with ConvLSTM encoders (for frame prediction) and a traditional Unet model (for segmentation mask prediction) was used on the 3D moving objects dataset.
Github Link : https://github.com/anishabhatnagar/Future-Frame-Prediction-and-Segmentation
projects.title: Future Frame Segmentation mask Prediction

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description: Images sampled from the CIFAR 100 dataset were converted to the LAB color space. The L channel values (grey scale information) were passed to the GAN while A and B channels (red-blue and yellow-green color information) were the target values to match. Three different GAN configurations were tested - Vanilla GAN (UNet) with BCE Logits loss, GAN with a Resnet -18 Backbone and BCE with logits loss, and GAN with a Resnet -18 backbone and PSNR loss. GAN with a Resnet -18 backbone and PSNR loss generated the best results. After training for 200 epochs, a high value of PSNR (= 33.6 dB)was achieved, showing a higher reconstruction quality.
projects.title: Image Colorisation using Conditional Generative Neural Networks

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description:
Kaggles Speaker Recognition Dataset, consisting of 5 speakers with single-channel audio samples, and a 16KHz sampling rate, was used for this project. Spectrograms, Mel - Spectrograms, and MFCC features were used as inputs into a ResNet-18 model.
An accuracy of 92.6% was achieved using the classic spectrograms, while an accuracy of 93.75% was achieved using Mel-Spectrograms. Using MFCC generated an accuracy of 95.3%. 
All implementation was done on Amazons AWS EC2 platform. This project was implemented using the PyTorch framework.
Github link: https://github.com/anishabhatnagar/Speaker_Recognition
projects.title: Identity Verification using Speech Signal Analysis and Feature Extraction

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning

projects.description: In this project, X-rays have been classified into two classes: 'fracture' and 'normal', using fastai deep learning library. The dataset was created using google images. Resnet34 and Resnet50 architectures were implemented. Maximum accuracy achieved was 72.28% using Resnet34 for learning rate between 3e-5 and 3e-3.
projects.title: Fracture Classifier

member.occupation: Researcher @ NYU - Courant | MS in CS | Software Engineering | Machine Learning
Technical Consulting Engineer at Cisco

projects.description: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is an inter autonomous system routing protocol to transfer data over the internet. Over the years, this protocol has suffered from some massive hits, caused by worms, hardware failures, and/or prefix hijacking. For this project, data for BGP transmissions for 109 hops was collected. The original dimensionality of the dataset was (126101,109). PCA and LDA technique was applied for dimensionality reduction, followed by training of Decision Tree, Random Forest, Adaboost, GradientBoosting classifiers. Further, the results of training different classifiers was analysed, from which the top two results obtained were for Random Forest with accuracy 97.84% and Decision Tree with accuracy 97.43%.
projects.title: Detection of Anomalies in Border Gateway Protocol Data
